G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14 (covenant of quie.raw_text: G.L. c. 186, § 14 (covenant of quiet enjoyment in residential tenancies).
G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14 (covenant of quie.proposition: This action is brought pursuant to the laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, including but not limited to G.L. c. 186, § 14 (covenant of quiet enjoyment in residential tenancies).

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19, 21.proposition: The Cambridge Division of the District Court Department has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19, 21, and related provisions, because this is a civil action for money damages arising out of a landlord‑tenant relationship and the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limits of this Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2..proposition: Venue is proper in the Cambridge District Court because the rental premises that are the subject of this dispute are located in Cambridge, Middlesex County, Massachusetts.

Linhart v. Boston Hous. Auth., 1 Mass. A.raw_text: Linhart v. Boston Hous. Auth., 1 Mass. App. Ct. 830 (1973)
Linhart v. Boston Hous. Auth., 1 Mass. A.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, whether or not expressly written in the lease.

Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.raw_text: Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124 (1959).
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, whether or not expressly written in the lease.
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.case_name: Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp.
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.support_reasoning: The case involves a commercial lease of business space, not a residential tenancy, and the court’s discussion of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction is in the commercial context. The opinion assumes the existence of a covenant of quiet enjoyment in this lease and treats the landlord’s failure to provide essential services as a breach, but it does not state or imply a general rule that every residential tenancy in Massachusetts carries an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the specific residential-tenancy proposition given.
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.relevant_excerpt: “Failure to furnish such services, at least if serious in extent and not excusable, deprives the lessee of a vital part of what the landlord knows the lessee must have in order to carry on his business. Such a failure constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment (see H. W. Robinson Carpet Co. v. Fletcher, 315 Mass. 350, 353…).”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Defendant, as Plaintiff’s landlord, owed Plaintiff a statutory and common‑law duty not to directly or indirectly interfere with her quiet enjoyment of the Apartment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses a landlord’s duty regarding a tenant’s quiet enjoyment, both under the common‑law implied covenant and under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court explains that every tenancy includes an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb the tenant’s quiet enjoyment, and it interprets § 14 to impose liability on a landlord who “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment” of residential premises. Thus, the case supports the proposition that the landlord owed the plaintiff both statutory and common‑law duties not to directly or indirectly interfere with her quiet enjoyment of the apartment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy… In relevant part, G. L. c. 186, § 14… [applies to] any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant….”

Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (.proposition: Defendant, as Plaintiff’s landlord, owed Plaintiff a statutory and common‑law duty not to directly or indirectly interfere with her quiet enjoyment of the Apartment.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses the nature of a landlord’s duty under the statutory (and codified common‑law) covenant of quiet enjoyment in G.L. c. 186, § 14. It explains that the statute ‘codified’ the common‑law implied covenant and that, as revised, it imposes liability where the landlord directly or indirectly interferes with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment through at least negligent conduct. Although the case’s main issue is whether a lead‑paint violation alone suffices, its reasoning affirms that landlords do owe tenants this statutory/common‑law duty not to directly or indirectly interfere with quiet enjoyment.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 186, § 14, originally enacted in 1927, codified a tenant’s common law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. … In 1973, the statute was rewritten and the requirement of intentional conduct was eliminated; landlords could now be held liable for ‘directly or indirectly’ interfering with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises. … Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord.

Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from acts or omissions by the landlord (or those for whom the landlord is responsible) that “materially impair the character and value of the leased premises.”
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.support_reasoning: The court expressly states that the lease carries an implied obligation that the lessor will refrain from voluntary acts that substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises, and links this to the tenant’s peaceful enjoyment. It further explains that landlord-authorized acts causing such substantial injury to the tenant’s enjoyment give rise to liability, aligning closely with the claimed formulation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.relevant_excerpt: “The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… If a landlord authorizes acts to be done which cause substantial injury to the tenant in the peaceful enjoyment of the demised premises and such a result is the natural and probable consequence of the acts so authorized, the landlord is liable therefor.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994);
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: A landlord’s liability for breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 extends to substantial interferences caused by the landlord’s agents, contractors, or persons acting under the landlord’s authority or control.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses landlord liability for breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but in the specific context of the landlord’s own omissions in responding to third-party criminal activity on common areas it owns and controls. It does not address, or extend liability to, actions by the landlord’s agents, contractors, or persons acting under the landlord’s authority; the focus is on the landlord’s failure to act rather than vicarious liability for those acting on its behalf. Thus, it does not support the specific proposition about liability for substantial interferences caused by agents or contractors.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: A landlord’s liability for breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 extends to substantial interferences caused by the landlord’s agents, contractors, or persons acting under the landlord’s authority or control.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely concerns a landlord’s direct failure to provide heat and the unavailability of a financial-inability defense under G.L. c. 186, § 14. It does not discuss, even implicitly, liability for substantial interferences caused by agents, contractors, or other persons acting under the landlord’s authority or control. The proposition about vicarious or derivative liability therefore is not supported by this case.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’… [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 717\.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, substantial interference with a tenant’s ability to use the leased premises in the manner reasonably contemplated by the tenancy—especially as a place of residence, repose, and, where known to the landlord, home‑based work—can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 717\.support_reasoning: The case clearly holds that substantial interference with residential tenants’ use and enjoyment of their apartments (here, loud late‑night bar noise preventing sleep and conversation) constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and supports a constructive eviction defense. The opinion frames the premises as “residential” and emphasizes that the apartments were no longer “reasonably habitable,” which aligns with interference with use as a place of residence and repose. The decision does not, however, specifically discuss home‑based work, so it only indirectly supports that portion of the proposition by analogy, not expressly.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 717\.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. Tenants such as these should not be left only with a claim against the proprietors of the noisome lounge… The judge… ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances… The noise… interfered with conversation and prevented sleep.”

Lynn v. Nashawaty, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 310.raw_text: Lynn v. Nashawaty, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 310, 314–15 (1981).
Lynn v. Nashawaty, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 310.proposition: The existence of reasonable hours alone does not excuse the landlord when the magnitude, duration, and intensity of the noise and dust substantially deprive the tenant of the beneficial use of the premises.
Lynn v. Nashawaty, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 310.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns misrepresentation of inventory value in the sale of a stationery store and the applicability of Massachusetts General Laws c. 93A to that transaction. It does not involve landlord–tenant law, noise or dust, reasonable hours, or constructive eviction/beneficial use concepts. Therefore it does not address, much less support, the stated proposition about noise and dust not being excused by reasonable hours.
Lynn v. Nashawaty, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 310.relevant_excerpt: In view of the position taken in the Begelfer case that an isolated transaction, one that does not take place in the ordinary course of business, may constitute a violation of § 11, so long as it takes place in a business context, it is difficult to avoid the conclusion reached by the finder of fact that the transaction at bar violated that section. We cannot say that the judge was required as matter of law to reach the conclusion that the sale of the stationery store did not take place “in a business context.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 787–88 (1994).
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: The landlord’s statutory duty under G.L. c. 186, § 14 is non‑waivable and cannot be avoided by limited or token compensation when the interference remains ongoing and substantial.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The opinion holds that negligent failure to repair serious code violations can constitute a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and entitles the tenant to statutory attorneys’ fees, but it does not address whether the landlord’s § 14 duty is non‑waivable or whether it cannot be satisfied by limited or token compensation while an ongoing substantial interference continues. The only waiver discussed is a tenant’s prior waiver of habitability claims for an earlier period, and the court does not analyze its validity under § 14. Nor does the decision discuss the adequacy of damages under § 14 in the face of ongoing interference. Thus it does not clearly support the specific proposition claimed.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 186, § 14 (1992 ed.), provides, in pertinent part, that “any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant ... shall ... be liable for actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.” … On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown. On remand, Thomas is entitled to reasonable attorney’s fees on this basis.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B;.proposition: Statutory damages and enhancements as provided under G.L. c. 186, § 14, to the extent applicable, together with interest as allowed by law, including G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
